q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Although intergroup prejudice has been recognized as one of the most important problems by social scientists, surprisingly little is known about what kind of interventions work in practice to reduce prejudice (Paluck and Green, 2009). While there exists a vast array of theories seeking to explain prejudice by social norms (Plant and Devine, 1998), or the structure of interaction between groups (Allport, 1954) and these theoretical results are often used to generate policy recommendations to reduce feelings of antipathy against out-group members, credible research designs are lacking and much of the empirical evidence is based on correlational studies or interventions on captive audiences in experimental labs (Paluck and Green, 2009). We contribute to this literature by testing the effect of an intervention that is based on replicated results of lab experiments but implemented on the field. As such, our study has the potential to combine the internal validity of laboratory experiments while achieving a greater extent of external validity (eg. Gerber and Green, 2012). The proposed intervention is an encouragement to play an online gamebook that allows players to take the perspective2 of a young Romani orphan who arrives at Budapest, Hungary to start a new life. The reader participates in the story by making choices that cause the narrative to branch along various potential paths.

q16.value: Our hypothesis is that participation in a role-playing game in which players need to take the perspective of a member of a marginalized minority reduces prejudice towards that minority.

q17.value: We evaluate the effect of participation in this game by inviting a sample of respondents to participate in an online survey, and randomly assign a subset of respondents to participate in the role-playing game. We measure prejudice both immediately after participation in the game (or after a set of background questions in the case of the control group) and in a later, second wave.

q19.value: 400 (based on response rates observed in pre-tests)

q27.value: The intervention (contained in the online survey)will be carried out by TARKI a Hungarian polling firm.

attributes.title: The distribution of cardiovascular risk scores in the Kenyan population and factors associated with risk score variation

q1.value: The distribution of cardiovascular risk scores in the Kenyan population and factors associated with risk score variation

q2.value: Tonny Brian Muthee, Anthony Etyang, Veronika Williams, Coral Milburn-Curtis, Carl heneghan, David Nunan

q3.value: Previous research exploring the distribution of the risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD) in Kenyan population has documented the prevalence of individual risk factors such as hypertension, cholesterol levels, blood glucose levels, smoking, various dietary habits and physical activity. There remains inadequate evidence as to the distribution of absolute risk for CVD based on combined risk factor assessment. Therefore, this study aims to describe the distribution of risk scores for CVD in the Kenyan adult population and to identify factors associated with the variation of these scores in this population.

q4.value:
We hypothesise that:

There will be several factors, including location (rural vs urban), county of residence, ethnicity, level of education, marital status, socio-economic status/wealth quintile, alcohol consumption (amount and frequency), fruit and vegetable intake (amount and frequency), sugar and salt intake (amount and frequency), physical activity (intensity and frequency), and prior lifestyle advice, that will contribute to variation in cardiovascular risk scores in this population.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A cross-sectional study of survey data

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: This dataset is publicly accessible via the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics – National Data Archive (KeNADA) under the Reference ID: KEN-KNBS-STEPS-2015-V0.1. We have avoided doing any initial analysis on this dataset up until now.

question.value:
The Kenya STEPwise Survey was carried out in 2015 between April and June as part of the international WHO STEPwise approach to surveillance of chronic disease risk factors. The details of the design of the survey have been published previously. Briefly, the survey employed a cross-sectional household design that targeted adults above the age of 18 years. 
Participants were selected in three stages from the fifth national sample surveys and evaluation programme (NASSEP V) master sample frame generated from the 2009 census data. Stage one involved the selection of Primary Sampling Units (PSUs), urban and rural clusters, using probability proportional to size (PPS) method. The second stage involved the selection of households, and finally, in the last stage, one adult was randomly selected using the Kish sampling method from the selected households. A total of 4500 eligible individuals were successfully interviewed in the survey. 
Data were collected via a modified eSTEPS tool (questionnaire). This tool collected data on four components; the demographic details of the participants, their behavioural risk factors, physical measurements, and biochemical risk factors for NCDs. Data collection was standardized and validated, and risk factor measurement clearly defined as per the WHO STEPS Surveillance Manual. This dataset is publicly accessible via the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics – National Data Archive (KeNADA) under the Reference ID: KEN-KNBS-STEPS-2015-V0.1.

We will estimate the absolute CVD risk over ten years for each eligible participant using the updated (2019) WHO/ISH risk calibrations for Eastern sub-Saharan Africa. This prediction model includes gender, age, SBP, total blood cholesterol, smoking status and the presence or absence of diabetes mellitus (type 1 or 2). 
To estimate this model on our dataset, we will start by deriving the Basic Risk Score equation (BRSe) used in the risk prediction model above and then calculating the risk probabilities for CHD/MI, Stroke and CVD. Lastly, the risk probability for CVD will be multiplied by 100 to get the 10-year CVD risk score in percentage.

Data were collected via a modified eSTEPS tool (questionnaire). This tool collected data on four components; the demographic details of the participants, their behavioural risk factors, physical measurements, and biochemical risk factors for NCDs. Data collection was standardized and validated, and risk factor measurement clearly defined as per the WHO STEPS Surveillance Manual. The definitions of these independent variables are as per the WHO STEPwise questionnaire and are attached below.

We will start by using descriptive statistics to calculate, graph and visualise data. This will include measures of central tendency (means and medians) and variation (standard deviations or interquartile ranges). We will then examine the association between variables by performing univariate analyses for independent variables and cardiovascular risk scores. Missing data on independent variables will be excluded from the analysis. 
Lastly, we will conduct a regression analysis to establish the relationship between the independent variables and cardiovascular risk. We will select the regression model with the best fit based on the adjusted R-squared value.

q23.value:
To address missing data for the calculation of CVD risk scores, i.e. total cholesterol and SBP readings, we will substitute with baseline figures per gender, region and age group as provided in Supplement Appendix 1 (Figures 1.12 and 1.13) of the revised models for WHO CVD Risk Charts paper.

Missing data on independent variables will be excluded from the analysis.

q25.value:
Ethics and Data Protection
We will be using publicly available information, and ethics committee approval is not required.

Dissemination
The findings of this study will contribute to TBM’s thesis for a Doctor of Philosophy at the University of Oxford. We will use the Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) statement guidelines to report our findings for publication in an academic journal. We will also participate in national and international scientific meetings by submitting findings for presentation. Further to this, we will also use other forms of media, such as social media and blog posts to communicate our findings to the public. We will also provide a summary of the findings to the Ministry of Health (Kenya) and other stakeholders.

Funding
No funding has been obtained to undertake this study.

Conflicts of Interest
TBM is funded by the Rhodes Trust for his Doctoral studies at the University of Oxford. CH has received expenses and fees for his media work (including payments from BBC Radio 4 Inside Health). He has received expenses from the WHO, Food Drug Administration (FDA), and holds grant funding from the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR), the NIHR School of Primary Care Research, The NIHR Biomedical Research Centre Oxford and the WHO. He has received financial remuneration from an asbestos case and to date has given legal advice on mesh cases. He has also received income from the publication of a series of toolkit books published by Blackwells. On occasion, he receives expenses for teaching Evidence Based Medicine (EBM) and is also paid for his GP work in National Health Service (NHS) out of hours (contract with Oxford Health NHS Foundation Trust).  He is the Director of Centre for Evidence Based Medicine (CEBM), which jointly runs the Evidence Live Conference with the British Medical Journal (BMJ) and the Overdiagnosis Conference with international partners, based on a non-profit making model. He is Editor in Chief of BMJ Evidence-Based Medicine and is an NIHR Senior Investigator.  DN has received expenses and fees for his media work (including payments from Channel 5). He has held grant funding from the NIHR and Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) to conduct independent research. He is also a voluntary (unpaid) member of the RCGP - Physical Activity and Lifestyle clinical priority steering committee. On occasion, he receives expenses for teaching EBM. AE, CMC and VW declare no conflicts of interest.

attributes.title: The Implications of Elite-Induced Opinion Change For Democratic Accountability

q1.value: The Implications of Elite-Induced Opinion Change For Democratic Accountability

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: A central focus of research on political communication is the extent to which messages from the media and political elites can change public opinion. Findings of elite-induced opinion change are routinely discussed in terms of their implications for voters’ subsequent political judgements and their bearing on notions of democratic accountability. Yet these assessments are largely indirect as scholars rarely examine the downstream consequences of changes in opinion brought about by elite messaging for citizens’ later political decisions. This leaves open an important question: under what conditions is elite-induced opinion change consequential for political accountability? We propose to examine this question using a novel experimental design that combines a political messaging experiment with a series of candidate evaluation tasks bringing together two common, but typically separate, designs

q16.value: H1: The largest amounts of opinion change due to issue frames will occur among individuals with weak predispositions on an issue. H2: Across issues, there will be an inverse relationship between the size of the framing effect and the degree to which that issue affects candidate evaluations. H3: The downstream effects of elite-induced opinion change will be more lim- ited than indicated by separate assessments of framing effects and the effects of issue agreement on candidate evaluations. More detail about these hypotheses and the manner in which they will be estimated is available in the attached pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: Detail about these hypotheses and the manner in which they will be estimated is available in the attached pre-analysis plan.

registration_responses.q15: A central focus of research on political communication is the extent to which messages from the media and political elites can change public opinion. Findings of elite-induced opinion change are routinely discussed in terms of their implications for voters’ subsequent political judgements and their bearing on notions of democratic accountability. Yet these assessments are largely indirect as scholars rarely examine the downstream consequences of changes in opinion brought about by elite messaging for citizens’ later political decisions. This leaves open an important question: under what conditions is elite-induced opinion change consequential for political accountability? We propose to examine this question using a novel experimental design that combines a political messaging experiment with a series of candidate evaluation tasks bringing together two common, but typically separate, designs
registration_responses.q16: H1: The largest amounts of opinion change due to issue frames will occur among individuals with weak predispositions on an issue. H2: Across issues, there will be an inverse relationship between the size of the framing effect and the degree to which that issue affects candidate evaluations. H3: The downstream effects of elite-induced opinion change will be more lim- ited than indicated by separate assessments of framing effects and the effects of issue agreement on candidate evaluations. More detail about these hypotheses and the manner in which they will be estimated is available in the attached pre-analysis plan.
registration_responses.q17: Detail about these hypotheses and the manner in which they will be estimated is available in the attached pre-analysis plan.

attributes.title: Dataset on termite trajectories in experimental arenas under varying social context
attributes.description: Here we present a dataset of trajectories of Cornitermes cumulans (Blattodea: Isoptera: Termitidae: Nasutitermitinae) termites confined in experimental arenas along with their nestmates. The assays consisted of tracking a focal termite worker inserted in groups composed of varying numbers of nestmates arranged in varying soldier: worker proportions.  We captured, every 0.5 s for 6 hours, the cartesian locations of the focal termite, using a video camera coupled to the software Ethovision XT. This allowed us to build the full trajectory of each focal termite in each arena along with the full extent of each assay. With more than 2 million data points, the set of termite trajectories provided here is the largest published so far.

q1.value: Dataset on termite trajectories in experimental arenas under varying social context

q2.value: G-Julieth Castiblanco, Paulo F. Cristaldo, Leticia R. de Paiva, Og DeSouza

q3.value:
The optimal foraging theory predicts that animals modulate the search strategy in response to the density and the quality of target resources [1-4]. Beyond food or shelter, conspecifics can be also essential targets not only as reproductive resources, as they also provide social interactions. This seems particularly true for social insects because interindividual contact is the base of key tasks such as foraging, defense or care for the offspring. Specifically for eusocial insects such as termites, contact with nestmates improves the survival of the individuals [5], even when poisoned [6] or infected with entomopathogenic fungi [7]. In order to locate this valuable resource, termite workers search for their nestmates using a foraging strategy which optimizes the location of sparse and scarce targets: the Lévy walks [8].  

The success of Lévy walks lies on the fact that individuals move about combining many steps of short lengths with a few large ones. By repeating this pattern at all scales, space is exploited fractally thereby allowing searchers to visit a maximum number of sites without revisiting areas or exhaustively inspecting the entire search space [9-11]. The advantages of Lévy walks have inspired the Lévy foraging hypothesis, which states that natural selection favours the preservation of this movement in animals [9,12]. However, an alternative theory predicts that Lévy walks are instinctive responses emerging from physical constraints in animals [8,13]. To reveal if the Lévy walks emerges as a consequence of natural selection or from simple physical constraints is a hot topic in animal movement research.   

To provide new evidence on such a gap, here we present the first large dataset of Cartesian positions of termite trajectories. In all, the dataset is composed of 2,272,426 Cartesian points obtained from the recordings of the trajectory of 75 focal termite workers of Cornitermes cumulans (Blattodea: Isoptera: Termitidae: Nasutitermitinae) each of them confined in a distinct arena. The focal termites were exposed to different target conditions to verify their ability to modulate the search pattern. As targets, we used their nestmates arranged in groups with variable numbers and caste composition (that is, distinct soldiers-to-workers proportions).

q4.value: If Lévy-like movements are adaptive in termites, then the individuals will use this strategy only for situations of scarce targets.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Controlled walking bioassays were performed using a causal design. Here we measure the effect of the density of the individuals (area occupied by termites divided by the total available to walk, independent variable) on the kinetics of one focal termite worker (dependent variable).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Ethical Statement:
The sample or experimental activities reported here were exempt of any specific permission. ODS holds a permanent collecting and transporting permit (# 33094) from IBAMA -The Brazilian Institute for the Environment and Renewable Natural Resources-. Tacit approval from the Brazilian Federal Government is implied by hiring ODS, PFC, and LRP as Scientific Researches, by awarding research grants to GJC, and by awarding ODS with a Fellowship from CNPq (The Brazilian Council for Research). Neither protected species were sampled nor genetical information was accessed.   
                                                                                                                                     
Model species:
Cornitermes spp. are Neotropical termites occurring in several habitats, including savannas ("Cerrado" in Brazil), grasslands, forest, and human-modified landscapes as crop areas and pastures [14]. Cornitermes cumulans builds nests with both an epigeal and subterranean part, being naturally distributed in Brazil (Central and Southern regions), Paraguay and Argentina [15]. The epigeal part of the nest of C. cumulans can reach 1.60 m of high and 0.95 m of circumference  [16], some even bigger nests being sometimes recorded.  The nest has two distinctive sections: (i) an internal mass -- typically black -- composed by chambers and galleries of thin walls (0.5 to 1 mm thick) built with a mix of fecal-material and plant remains [16]; and (ii) the external section -- surrounding the central mass -- composed of chambers and galleries of thick walls (5 to 9 cm thick) built with clay [16]. The constructions of Cornitermes cumulans harbor a large amount of arthropods including other species of termites [17,18] by which C. cumulans is considered a keystone species [17]. 

Study area:
Termite soldiers and workers were sampled from 13 nests of  C. cumulans with no sign of damage in the Brazilian Atlantic Forest biome, on pastureland in the municipality of Viçosa (S20°45', W42°52'), Minas Gerais State, Southeastern Brazil. The sampling was made in two periods, the first from 23rd July 2014 to 26th September 2014; the second from 3rd February 2015 to 3rd June 2015. In Köppen system, the study area corresponds to Cfb climate (subtropical climate, without dry season and temperate summer) [19]. The maximum and minimum temperature registered for the 2014 period was 16.9°C - 20.1°C, and for the 2015 period was 18.3°C - 23.1°C; the precipitation during the two study periods, ranged from 0.0 mm to 12.2 mm and from 0.0 mm to 110.4mm, respectively [20]. 

Movement recordings:  Walking experiment
Controlled walking bioassays were performed with groups (75) composed by a different number of soldiers and workers in three distinct global densities (see Table 1). Assays consisted of continuously tracking the movement of one focal worker confined in an experimental arena with no obstacle, food or water, along up to 6 hours. Arenas consisted of a glass Petri dish (⌀ =53 mm) placed upside down over a sand-blasted flat glass (Fig. 1). 
To allow the optimal contrast for detection by the tracking equipment, the focal worker was painted with a nontoxic mixture composed of white glue + dye as described by [21].

Trajectories of the focal individuals were systematically collected at a sample rate of one Cartesian position every 0.5 s over 6 h, with the video-tracking software EthovisionXT (Version 8.5.614, Noldus Information Technology) coupled with a video camera (Panasonic WV-BP334) hence producing series of 43 thousand Cartesian points. A total of 22 experimental combinations of termite soldiers and workers were conducted. Each combination was composed of a given number of soldiers and workers comprising a particular global density (see table 1). These combinations resulted in a total of 14 different densities of termite workers.

q13.value: In all, the dataset is composed of 2,272,426 Cartesian points obtained from the recordings of the trajectory of 75 focal termite workers of Cornitermes cumulans.

question.value:
We manipulated the density of termites at two scales:
1. Changing the total number of termites despite their caste (workers plus soldiers) in the Petri-dish. Named global density. 
2. Modifying the proportion of the castes (workers and soldiers) preserving the global density. The density of castes.  

At all, we tested 3 global densities: 0.08, 0.12 and 0.20; and 13 densities of castes (from 0.01 to 0.20).

The kinetics of the focal termite workers was measured through: 
1. The search strategy. 
2. The mean speed of displacement.  

Both, the search strategy and the mean speed were calculated from the analysis of the Cartesian positions of the termite workers.
In order to test the hypothesis, we will use a Generalized Linear Modelling (GLM) under normal error distribution.

q22.value: Data series with less than 16 thousand Cartesian points after the processing were excluded.

q23.value: As a consequence of the assay conditions, sometimes the focal termite fell on its back preventing the detection by the tracking equipment of the white dot painted on the abdomen. Such an eventuality generated missed samples. To resolve these cases, fragments of data series with up to ten consecutive missed samples were interpolated. To interpolate, we assumed that termites walked in a straight line from the Cartesian position before the first gap to the Cartesian position after the last missed sample. Raw data series containing fragments exceeding ten consecutive missed samples were truncated from the first gap to the end of the data series (that is, only the initial intact fragment has been used in the analyses). The interpolations were made using a Fortran algorithm.

q25.value:
The procedures reported here correspond to the dataset published at the Zenodo repository. 
DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.3628061
Link: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3628061

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will advertise this “time 2” survey on MTurk to all of the 500 workers who participated in the “time 1” survey. Our sample size will be the number of workers who complete this “time 2” survey within a 2-week period.

analyses.value: We will conduct 3 separate paired t-tests, comparing participants’ scores on our 3 outcomes—political ideology, moral foundations purity, and endorsement of precarious manhood—at time 2 versus time 1. To test whether effects are moderated by participants’ levels of concern with the coronavirus pandemic, we will conduct 3 separate mixed ANOVAs, one for each outcome; in each ANOVA, the within-subjects factor will be time (time 1 vs. time 2) and the between-subjects factor level of pandemic concern (low vs. high). If an interaction effect between time and concern is significant, then we will follow up by conducting simple main effects of time within each level of concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail an attention check in this “time 2” survey or if they failed an attention check in the “time 1” survey.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables include political ideology, moral foundations purity, and endorsement of precarious manhood.

Political ideology will be assessed by the following question: “On the following scale from 1 (very liberal) to 7 (very conservative), how would you rate your political views?”

Concern for moral foundations purity will be assessed by the 3-item purity subscale of the Moral Foundations Questionnaire, which measures the extent to which considerations of purity are relevant to participants’ moral judgments. An example item is “whether or not someone did something disgusting.” Responses will range from 1 (not at all relevant) to 6 (extremely relevant).

Endorsement of precarious manhood will be assessed by the following seven items: “It’s fairly easy for a man to lose his status as a man,” “A male’s status as a real man sometimes depends on how other people view him,” “A man needs to prove his masculinity,” “A boy needs to become a man; it doesn’t ‘just happen',” “The title of ‘manhood’ needs to be reserved for those who deserve it,” “You’re not a man if you don’t like masculine things,” and “A real man enjoys a bit of danger now and then,” with responses ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

A moderator variable will be the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic. This will be assessed by the question, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses including “not at all,” “somewhat concerned,” “very concerned,” and “extremely concerned.” Participants who indicate that they are either “not at all” or “somewhat concerned” will be categorized as low in concern, whereas participants who indicate that they are either “very concerned” or “extremely concerned” will be categorized as high in concern.

conditions.value: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.

hypothesis.value: The present study will be a “time 2” assessment for a larger longitudinal study. Thus, all participants will have participated in the “time 1” study, in which we assessed political ideology, moral foundations purity, and endorsement of precarious manhood. We will test whether people’s scores on these variables changed with the development of the coronavirus pandemic. We hypothesize that, compared to before the pandemic (time 1), after the start of the pandemic (time 2), people will report more conservative political ideology, stronger reliance on moral foundations purity, and greater endorsement of precarious manhood. We hypothesize that these effects will be moderated by the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic, being larger for participants who are high in concern than for participants who are low in concern.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will recruit 500 participants. We will set Qualtrics to randomly present participants with one of the two conditions. Thus, we expect to recruit approximately 250 participants in the prime condition and 250 participants in the control condition.

analyses.value:
We will conduct 4 separate independent samples t-tests—one for each eating outcome—to test whether the manipulation had significant effects on eating behavior attitudes. We will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. We will conduct 3 separate independent samples t-tests—one for each eating disgust score—to test whether the manipulation had significant effects on disgust. We will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups.

We will conduct 3 separate mediation models using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R in order to test whether effects of the manipulation on each of these three outcomes—willingness to try cultured meat, to try durian, and to try insects—is mediated by disgust toward each eating behavior.

For more parsimonious data analysis, we will compute 2 new variables to represent “food disgust” and “food-specific neophobia.” Our food disgust variable will be the mean of participants’ disgust scores for cultured meat, insects, and durian. Our food-specific neophobia will be the reverse-scored mean of participants’ willingness scores for cultured meat, insects, and durian. Food-general neophobia will be the 5-item neophobia scale described above. Then, for moderation analyses, we will conduct 3 separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of the manipulation on each of these outcomes—food disgust, food-specific neophobia, and food-general neophobia—differs by level of pandemic concern. For food disgust, we will regress food disgust on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For food-specific neophobia, we will regress food-specific neophobia on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For food-general neophobia, we will regress food-general neophobia on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are unfamiliar with the coronavirus pandemic, report that they are vegetarian, fail an attention check in the survey, or enter that they are an unpermitted (<18 years) age.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables include willingness to try cultured meat, to try durian, and to try insects, as well as food neophobia.

Prior to indicating their willingness to try cultured meat, participants will read the following prompt: “We are curious to hear what you think about “in vitro meat.” In vitro meat is an animal flesh product that has never been part of a living animal, but is instead grown in a laboratory using muscle stem cells. In vitro meat is also referred to as cultured meat, cell-based meat, or synthetic meat. In August 2013, scientists unveiled (and tasted) the world's first in vitro grown hamburger patty. Currently, in vitro meat is not commercially available, though research is being conducted to introduce it as a potential new meat production technique for the future.” Willingness to try cultured meat will then be assessed by the question, “Would you be willing to try in vitro meat?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including no, definitely not (1); no, probably not (2); unsure (3); yes, maybe (4); and yes, definitely (5).

Prior to indicating their willingness to try durian, participants will read the following prompt: “We are curious to hear what you think about durian. Durian is an exotic fruit that is known for tasting sweet and creamy but, at the same time, for smelling horrible. In fact, the smell of durian is so offensive that durian has been banned from being eaten in many public areas. Even despite the offensive smell of durian, some people still enjoy eating durian for its pleasant taste.” Willingness to try durian will then be assessed by the question, “Would you be willing to taste durian?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including no, definitely not (1); no, probably not (2); unsure (3); yes, maybe (4); and yes, definitely (5).

Prior to indicating their willingness to try insects, participants will read the following prompt: “We are curious to hear what you think about eating insects. Nowadays, it is becoming more common for people to eat insects, such as crickets and grasshoppers. Many people have described insects as tasting nutty and earthy.” Willingness to try insects will then be assessed by the question, “Would you be willing to taste insects?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including no, definitely not (1); no, probably not (2); unsure (3); yes, maybe (4); and yes, definitely (5).

Food neophobia will be assessed by the following 5 items: “I don’t trust new foods,” “If I don’t know what is in a food, I won’t try it,” “I am afraid to eat things I have never had before,” “I am very particular about the foods I will eat,” and “I will eat almost anything” (reverse-scored). Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Mediator variables include disgust toward each of the 3 eating behaviors listed above (all outcomes except for food neophobia). Disgust toward each behavior will be assessed by a 3-item scale. The disgust scale for each behavior will follow the same format. The 3 items for disgust toward cultured meat, for example, are, “In vitro meat is disgusting,” “The thought of eating in vitro meat makes me nauseous,” and “In vitro meat is gross.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

The manipulation in this study is whether participants reflect on the coronavirus pandemic before or after they complete the dependent measures. Participants will reflect on the pandemic in the following manner. First, participants be asked, “Have you heard about the current coronavirus pandemic?” to which responses include “yes” and “no.” Second, participants will be asked, “Please take a moment to reflect on the coronavirus pandemic and how you feel about it...” Third, participants will be asked, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses including “not at all,” “somewhat concerned,” “moderately concerned,” “very concerned,” and “extremely concerned.”

A moderator variable will be the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic. This will be assessed by the question within the manipulation, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses from “not at all” to “extremely concerned” scored respectively from 1 to 5.

conditions.value: There are two conditions in this survey: a “coronavirus prime” condition and a “no prime” control condition. Participants will be randomly assigned to one condition. Participants in the prime condition will complete the manipulation task before completing any dependent measures, whereas participants in the control condition will complete the dependent measures before the manipulation task.

hypothesis.value: We will test whether reflecting on the coronavirus pandemic changes people’s attitudes toward their eating behaviors. We hypothesize that upon reflecting on the pandemic, participants will report that they are less willing to try cultured meat, to try durian, or to try insects. We hypothesize that these effects will be mediated by disgust toward each eating behavior, with disgust being higher upon reflecting on the pandemic. We hypothesize that upon reflecting on the pandemic, participants will report being more food neophobic. We hypothesize that all of these effects will be moderated by the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic, being larger for participants who are high in concern than for participants who are low in concern.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Coronavirus Eating Experiment
registration_responses.sample: We will recruit 500 participants. We will set Qualtrics to randomly present participants with one of the two conditions. Thus, we expect to recruit approximately 250 participants in the prime condition and 250 participants in the control condition.
registration_responses.analyses:
We will conduct 4 separate independent samples t-tests—one for each eating outcome—to test whether the manipulation had significant effects on eating behavior attitudes. We will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. We will conduct 3 separate independent samples t-tests—one for each eating disgust score—to test whether the manipulation had significant effects on disgust. We will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups.

We will conduct 3 separate mediation models using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R in order to test whether effects of the manipulation on each of these three outcomes—willingness to try cultured meat, to try durian, and to try insects—is mediated by disgust toward each eating behavior.

For more parsimonious data analysis, we will compute 2 new variables to represent “food disgust” and “food-specific neophobia.” Our food disgust variable will be the mean of participants’ disgust scores for cultured meat, insects, and durian. Our food-specific neophobia will be the reverse-scored mean of participants’ willingness scores for cultured meat, insects, and durian. Food-general neophobia will be the 5-item neophobia scale described above. Then, for moderation analyses, we will conduct 3 separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of the manipulation on each of these outcomes—food disgust, food-specific neophobia, and food-general neophobia—differs by level of pandemic concern. For food disgust, we will regress food disgust on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For food-specific neophobia, we will regress food-specific neophobia on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For food-general neophobia, we will regress food-general neophobia on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.
registration_responses.outliers: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are unfamiliar with the coronavirus pandemic, report that they are vegetarian, fail an attention check in the survey, or enter that they are an unpermitted (<18 years) age.
registration_responses.dependent:
Dependent variables include willingness to try cultured meat, to try durian, and to try insects, as well as food neophobia.

Prior to indicating their willingness to try cultured meat, participants will read the following prompt: “We are curious to hear what you think about “in vitro meat.” In vitro meat is an animal flesh product that has never been part of a living animal, but is instead grown in a laboratory using muscle stem cells. In vitro meat is also referred to as cultured meat, cell-based meat, or synthetic meat. In August 2013, scientists unveiled (and tasted) the world's first in vitro grown hamburger patty. Currently, in vitro meat is not commercially available, though research is being conducted to introduce it as a potential new meat production technique for the future.” Willingness to try cultured meat will then be assessed by the question, “Would you be willing to try in vitro meat?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including no, definitely not (1); no, probably not (2); unsure (3); yes, maybe (4); and yes, definitely (5).

Prior to indicating their willingness to try durian, participants will read the following prompt: “We are curious to hear what you think about durian. Durian is an exotic fruit that is known for tasting sweet and creamy but, at the same time, for smelling horrible. In fact, the smell of durian is so offensive that durian has been banned from being eaten in many public areas. Even despite the offensive smell of durian, some people still enjoy eating durian for its pleasant taste.” Willingness to try durian will then be assessed by the question, “Would you be willing to taste durian?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including no, definitely not (1); no, probably not (2); unsure (3); yes, maybe (4); and yes, definitely (5).

Prior to indicating their willingness to try insects, participants will read the following prompt: “We are curious to hear what you think about eating insects. Nowadays, it is becoming more common for people to eat insects, such as crickets and grasshoppers. Many people have described insects as tasting nutty and earthy.” Willingness to try insects will then be assessed by the question, “Would you be willing to taste insects?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including no, definitely not (1); no, probably not (2); unsure (3); yes, maybe (4); and yes, definitely (5).

Food neophobia will be assessed by the following 5 items: “I don’t trust new foods,” “If I don’t know what is in a food, I won’t try it,” “I am afraid to eat things I have never had before,” “I am very particular about the foods I will eat,” and “I will eat almost anything” (reverse-scored). Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Mediator variables include disgust toward each of the 3 eating behaviors listed above (all outcomes except for food neophobia). Disgust toward each behavior will be assessed by a 3-item scale. The disgust scale for each behavior will follow the same format. The 3 items for disgust toward cultured meat, for example, are, “In vitro meat is disgusting,” “The thought of eating in vitro meat makes me nauseous,” and “In vitro meat is gross.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

The manipulation in this study is whether participants reflect on the coronavirus pandemic before or after they complete the dependent measures. Participants will reflect on the pandemic in the following manner. First, participants be asked, “Have you heard about the current coronavirus pandemic?” to which responses include “yes” and “no.” Second, participants will be asked, “Please take a moment to reflect on the coronavirus pandemic and how you feel about it...” Third, participants will be asked, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses including “not at all,” “somewhat concerned,” “moderately concerned,” “very concerned,” and “extremely concerned.”

A moderator variable will be the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic. This will be assessed by the question within the manipulation, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses from “not at all” to “extremely concerned” scored respectively from 1 to 5.

summary.value:
Original Citation: Shnabel, Nurit, and Arie Nadler. "A needs-based model of reconciliation: satisfying the differential emotional needs of victim and perpetrator as a key to promoting reconciliation." Journal of personality and social psychology 94.1 (2008): 116.

Target of replication: The current study seeks to replicate the findings that participants in the perpetrator condition would indicate a need for social acceptance and be more likely to reconcile after their sense of moral acceptance was restored, whereas participant in the victim condition would indicate a need for power and would be more likely to reconcile after their sense of power was restored. It specifically focuses on the interaction between message and role in the after condition. More detail can be found in the replication report.
